column2: In the absence of any definition provided in the Penal Code either to

column1: a “fight” or to a “quarrel”, in the context of the contentions that were placed
before this Court, it  is helpful to consider the words “fight”  and “quarrel”
for its general meaning in the English language, in order to understand the

purpose  of 
inserting 
these
Exception.

column2: The  general  dictionary  meaning  of  a  “quarrel”  is  given  as  “a  heated

column1: argument or disagreement, typically about a trivial issue and between people who
are usually on good terms” whereas the meaning of “fight” is given as to “take
part  in  a  violent  struggle  involving  the  exchange  of  physical  blows  or  the  use  of
weapons”.    The  meaning  attributed  to  the  word  “quarrel”  by  Black’s  Law
Dictionary  (5th  ED),
column2: is  “an  altercation,  an  angry  dispute,  an  exchange  of

column1: recriminations, taunts, threats or accusations between two persons” whereas the

meaning 
to 
the  word  “fight”
column3: is  described  as  a  hostile  encounter  or

column1: engagement  between  opposing  forces  suggesting  primarily  the  notion  of
brawl or unpremeditated encounter following a judicial pronouncement in
Gitlow v Kiely, D.C.N.Y. 44 F.2d 227, 232.

column2: The  dictionary  meaning  of  these  two  words  might  not  necessarily

column1: convey the entire scope of the words ‘quarrel’ and ‘fight’, as found in the
